ABSTRACT

Three new composites containing perylene diimides derivates covalently bonded to graphene oxide were obtained and their photophysical properties were studied. The imidated perylenes were prepared by condensing the perylene dianhydride with ethyldiamine (PEDI2), 3-aminopropyl triethoxysil ane (APTES) , and decyldiamine (PEDI10) , and then the GO was placed in the presence of the PEDI derivate , originating the respective covalently bonded GO/PEDI2, GO/APTES -PEDI , and GO/PEDI10 . The photophysical studies showed that both GO/PEDI2 and GO/PEDI10 composites were able to generate singlet oxygen (1O2) when perylene diimides did not form ÔÅ∞-stacking with GO. Semi -empirical calculations with PM6 - DH2X (MOPAC 2016) confirmed the photophysical results and showed that perylene diimides could form three different structures when bonded to GO: (1) parallel to GO, forming ÔÅ∞- stacking interaction; (2) parallel to GO, but not superimposed ÔÅ∞-systems (pns -ÔÅ∞), and; (3) perpendicular to the GO molecular plane (T-shape). Finally, the photochemical reactivities of these two covalently modified composites were confirmed by an increase in bacterial inhibition (more than 80%) when E. coli is irradiated when compared to GO in the dark condition . On the other hand, t he GO/APTES -PEDI derivative presents a different photop hysical behavior since no relevant results were observed regarding the generation of singlet oxygen. This new material showed to be capable of stabilizing the electron/ hole pair initiated by perylene diimides excimers formed after excitation in the visibl e range. This property has a direct relation with the APTES -PEDI derivative since the modification using this molecule act as a simple chemical method to force excimer formation. Theoretical calculations show that the structures in which GO is perpendicular to the perylene core are more prompt to form the anion radical than pure GO, indicating that perpendicular excimers could play an important role in stabilizing electrons. In this way, t he GO/APTES -PEDI was applie d in the photocatalytic degradation of methylene blue dye (MB). Thus, efficient removal of 90% of methylene blue was observed, since the photodegradation mechanism of a dye depends on the efficient separation and mobility of carriers.
